page.title: 15Gloucester Flying Machine
page.content: Of all the coaches the Gloucester Flying machine was the most famous. It was the first coach to be fitted with steel springs on the London-Gloucester road. The journey took two days. The Gloucester Flying machine made its first run in April 1756, leaving the yard of the Kings Head in Westgate Street, Gloucester at three o'clock in the morning and picking up passengers at the coach office in Northgate Street whuch was opened by John Turner in November 1755. The first stop was the Frogmill. There passengers from Cheltenham joined the coach and after a change of horses the journey was continued through Burford and Witney to Oxford. At the New Inn in St. Aldates, Oxford, the flying machine was laid up for the night. At five o'clock the next morning the coach left Oxford by Magdalen Bridge.
